title: Day 1336
content:
# Day 1336

![Modern Art - [https://x.com/ConorChepenik/status/1990572698301268166?s=20](https://x.com/ConorChepenik/status/1990572698301268166?s=20)](https://miro.medium.com/0*lvBs41-_KAFRLPku)

What we are witnessing here is nothing less than a seismic detonation of post-neo-expressionist chromatic violence. The artist has liberated pigment from the tyranny of intention, allowing raw, unfiltered id to erupt in ecstatic, primordial splatters.

Observe the courageous deployment of what lesser minds might call "neon orange"...but no, this is clearly a searing indictment of late stage capitalist sunset anxiety, a molten scream against the Anthropocene sky. The magenta vortex in the lower left? A clear Lacanian confrontation with the Real, dragging the viewer kicking and screaming into the abyss of the unattainable objet petit a.

And then *transcendence* the solitary black aperture near the top, a void so profound it functions as both cosmological singularity and ironic winking critique of the institutional white cube. Is it a portal? A bullet hole in the fabric of bourgeois meaning-making? Both. Neither. Everything. The faint scribbles in metallic marker are not mere "doodles," darling; they are automatic writing from the collective unconscious, a direct fax from the Jungian shadow realm.

This piece doesn't just hang on the wall, it colonizes your soul, redecorates your trauma, and then charges you $280,000 for the privilege. I am shaking. I am undone. This is the most important hotel keycard-based poly-material intervention since Basquiat discovered the Xerox machine.

...jk my 2 year old painted this and I like it. But that's how I imagine many modern art critics write about what appears to be a bunch of scribbles.

And since we are treating today's Medium post like a mixed-media installation, a stray thought hit me while writing it. We are not far from the moment where I can tell an AI, "Scrape my entire Medium archive, compress it, load it into your memory, and talk to me like you are me." A model that knows my patterns better than I do. A mirror that does more than reflect and starts interpreting my thoughts with me.

Maybe one day someone even offers a brain scan, a neural export feature, a way to feed the raw source code of a mind into a machine. Will it work? Hard to say. If memory is more hologram than hard drive, distributed, reconstructive, always shifting, maybe the scan would miss the point entirely. I am sure there will still be value in checking that a brain is healthy, but maybe we will never capture memory with the fidelity we had hoped for when we set out to make someone's mind synthetic.

Still, it leaves an interesting question: If an AI can learn your patterns, your quirks, your obsessions, your writing tics, does that count as "you"? Or is it just another critic describing the splatters?

See what I did there XD

11/17/25

Conor Jay Chepenik
